message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Scar formation is a part of the healing process of acute inflammation, and it involves fibroblast proliferation and deposition of extracellular matrix components. Chickenpox lesions heal by re-epithelialization, leaving a small scar. While scars are mostly permanent, over time they may fade and become less noticeable. Option A is incorrect as complete resolution of acute inflammation does not always result in scars. Option C is also incorrect as not all scars are permanent and may fade over time. Option D is incorrect as neutrophils, plasma cells, and macrophages are not predominant in chickenpox lesions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The formation of scars is a part of the healing process of acute inflammation, as it is a result of tissue repair and new collagen formation. The other options are not accurate: complete resolution of acute inflammation does not always lead to scarring, scars are not always permanent and can fade, and the cells involved in scar formation are primarily fibroblasts, not neutrophils, plasma cells, and macrophages.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The formation of scars is a part of the healing process of acute inflammation. However, in some cases, the scars may be permanent. Neutrophils, plasma cells, and macrophages are involved in the acute inflammatory response but do not play a significant role in scar formation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chickenpox is caused by the Varicella-zoster virus and is known for causing skin lesions that can scar. The formation of scars is part of the healing process of acute inflammation. Option A is incorrect as scars do not represent complete resolution of acute inflammation. Option C is also incorrect as not all scars from chickenpox remain for life. Option D is incorrect as the predominant cells in these lesions are T-lymphocytes and eosinophils.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The formation of scars is a part of the healing process of acute inflammation. Chickenpox lesions heal without scarring in most cases, but scarring can occur if the lesions are scratched and become infected. Neutrophils are the predominant cells in acute inflammation, but in healing, fibroblasts and collagen play important roles in scar formation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The chickenpox lesions go through a healing process involving re-epithelialization and collagen deposition, which can result in scars. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. Option (A) is incorrect because scars are not equivalent to complete resolution of acute inflammation. Option (C) is incorrect because not all chickenpox cases result in permanent scarring. Option (D) is incorrect because neutrophils, plasma cells, and macrophages are not the predominant cells in the formation of chickenpox scars.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The healing process of chickenpox involves the formation of new blood vessels, collagen synthesis, and re-epithelialization. Scarring occurs as a part of the healing process of acute inflammation. The scars may fade over time but are not completely resolved. Neutrophils are predominant in the early acute inflammatory phase but are replaced by macrophages and lymphocytes in the later stages.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Scarring is a part of the healing process of acute inflammation, especially in cases where there is damage to the dermis layer of the skin such as with chickenpox vesicles. The scars may not be permanent in all cases and the types of cells present in the lesions may vary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Scarring after chickenpox is a part of the healing process of acute inflammation. The scars may fade over time but can be permanent in some cases. Neutrophils, plasma cells, and macrophages are involved in acute inflammation but are not necessarily the predominant cells in the formation of scars.

Neutrophils, plasma cells, and macrophages are not the predominant cells in healing of chickenpox lesions.
